caption:
This photograph captures two men engaged in an interaction beside a small aircraft. The first man, standing outside the aircraft, is dressed in a yellow shirt and dark pants. He is examining a piece of paper that the second man, who is sitting inside the aircraft, is handing to him. The second man, who appears to be the pilot, is wearing a helmet and a vest, and is seated inside the open cockpit of the plane.

The aircraft is small and white with a stripe pattern that includes red and darker tones, and the number "235" is visibly painted in red on the side of the cockpit door. The scene is set against a backdrop of a clear blue sky with very few clouds, suggesting a fair weather day ideal for flying.

The interaction seems to be focused possibly on a flight plan or a logbook, typical of pre-flight or post-flight procedures in aviation. The setting and attire suggest a casual, possibly private or small regional aviation environment rather than a commercial or military setting. The overall mood captured in the image is one of professionalism and attentiveness to the task at hand.
title: Deputy agricultural commissioner Conrad Schilling and pilot John Gilbert prepare for flight over barley fields. They will spread grain poisoned by zinc phosphide in an attempt to eradicate harmful squirrel colonies. The grain will be spread in a particular pattern which will not threaten other animals.
